title: Tax hacks: how I increased my state pension by 50pc
text:
In Tax Hacks, our columnist Mike Warburton – previously a tax director with accountants Grant Thornton – brings you his best tax-saving tips

According to a recent report Britain's state pension was the lowest out of the 35 developed countries examined.

Someone starting work today can expect to retire on a state pension of about 29pc of the average wage compared with the OECD average of 63pc.

In particular, married women have been let down and the recent ruling by the High Court against the "Waspi" campaign group is a further blow.

Anyone reaching state pension age on or after April 6 2016 should qualify for the new state pension. The maximum is currently £168.80 a week (or £8,777.60 a year)...
